@adriarichards amen.
@disambiguated you are the authority on whether people you've never met have experienced racism or sexism?
@disambiguated I'm a blogger *and* I work for a living. Two jobs. Providing jobs for dozens more people. Your condescension is revealing.
@disambiguated you're saying the near-total lack of african american startup founders isn't evidence of a systemic problem of exclusion?
@disambiguated actually, racism is almost *exactly* like an environmental condition. It's a societal one. It pervades an atmosphere.
@disambiguated please: do publish a transcript of both our conversations tonight. I am quite comfortable with what I've said.
@erickschonfeld @arrington @wadhwa nobody actually is saying @arrington is racist. We're saying racism exists in society, including in SV.
@disambiguated you don't care if more people have opportunities. at least you're public about it.
@disambiguated you know "some of my best friends are black" is the most cliche response to have in these conversations?
@Klitzy when did you see the documentary?
@disambiguated amazing how you know that since you don't notice race or gender! it's almost as if what you were saying wasn't true.
@disambiguated I hope you never have a daughter.
@disambiguated you believe there's presently equality of opportunity in the startup world?
@disambiguated so your belief is that there are few black startup founders because black people don't have good ideas & work hard.
@EliHaven nobody's arguing otherwise. Some *are* saying blacks/women aren't more present in startups because they don't have good ideas.
@disambiguated don't pretend to respect MLK & then describe a passion for social justice as "sniveling" while condescending to me.
@disambiguated hard work + ambition + good ideas = success? So women & minorities don't succeed in the Valley because they don't have these?
@disambiguated all of us who are minorities who have good ideas and ambitions care. I believe that you don't care about that, though.
@thepartycow are you familiar with http://t.co/PFjMAn9k ? May provide some context for what I'm talking about.
@thepartycow being able to *not* have to think about race or gender is a privilege. Those who are excluded don't have that privilege.
@nathanrobertson it's a non-issue that women and minorities are underrepresented in the startup community?

FWIW, I respect @arrington & appreciate his provocation, but think he just hasn't truly listened to minority perspectives in many cases yet.
@xeni 100% truth.
@jesseseguin sometimes it's just not being educated on those topics because you have the privilege to not have to be.
@blam eh, I don't do drama. I will have a conversation with anybody who is willing to actually listen, though. Usually @arrington will.
@arrington fair enough - not my intent to attack you, but just show a perspective i have access to that you might now.
@arrington btw, do appreciate you engaging -- I think if you stay open-minded on this you'll find a story you'll be sad to discover.
@arrington no, sorry -- mixed up threads. "golf course" doesn't have to be literal to represent that closer friends get better terms.
@arrington you're actually saying "hey brown guy and women, you have no idea about being a minority, trust me" right now?
@tiffani well, and only a certain *kind* of press. "Soft" coverage, in particular verticals. It's not gonna work for a female chip maker.
@sayitaintsho absolutely 100% correct. Plus it would overshadow their actual entrepreneurship.
@Mona what self-respecting woman would want to turn an unwanted proposition into a business relationship?
@Mona with respect, that's absurd. "handle properly" an inappropriate proposition? How could it be advantageous?
@arrington You're looking at "get funded" very narrowly. More important: "get to the point where you'd think of getting funded".
@arrington @mona it's not a simple binary. There are some instances where it can help, but I'd guess far more where it's a negative.
@arrington Maybe they *should*, but I understand why they don't. I'm very lucky but don't have time/desire to pick fights with millionaires.
@wadhwa FWIW, I think @arrington can be empathetic about it, but starts by being defensive. To be fair, he does that with everything. ;)
@arrington Keep in mind, your connections/visibility would make people less likely to reveal it to you if they're feeling vulnerable.
@arrington They had no reason to make it up, and it only came up as we commiserated over the struggles/frustrations.
@arrington And they can't talk about it because they'd be blackballed or it would overshadow the *actual work* they want to do.
@arrington prominent female founders whom you & I both know have told me about VCs responding to their pitches with propositions. Regularly.
@arrington key thing here is you're saying "women and people of color never have issues in SV" but how could you possibly know that?
Even after all this time, still amazes me when @arrington presumes to speak as an authority on the experiences of women & people of color.
